updated_fields.chief_complaints: follow up for a known bile duct stricture, history of hilar biliary stricture and chronic calcific pancreatitis
updated_fields.past_medical_history: history of hilar biliary stricture and chronic calcific pancreatitis
updated_fields.stricture_description: mild, short, hilar stricture measuring approximately 5 mm, extending from the hilum bile duct
impressions: Successful removal of prior 10 French by 15 cm plastic stent
Successful deep cannulation of bile duct with sphincterotome and guidewire
Cholangiogram revealed mild, short, hilar stricture measuring approximately 5 mm
Successful placement of new 10 French by 15 cm plastic stent

updated_sections.indications: A 19-year-old male patient is here for an ERCP procedure for follow-up of a known bile duct stricture, history of hilar biliary stricture, and chronic calcific pancreatitis.
updated_sections.history: The patient reports a history of follow-up for a known bile duct stricture, history of hilar biliary stricture, and chronic calcific pancreatitis. Initially, there was concern for malignancy, but prior biopsies and imaging showed no evidence of progression, suggesting a benign etiology. No history of progression of malignancy is reported unless otherwise specified.
updated_sections.findings: A scout film of the abdomen was performed and appeared normal, with a biliary stent in situ. The duodenoscope Olympus TJF Q180V was advanced to the second portion of the duodenum without difficulty and without detailed examination of the upper GI tract. The major papilla was identified and appeared normal in position and morphology, with an intact orifice and no surrounding erythema or edema. After removal of the previously placed stent, evidence of prior sphincterotomy was present, and the orifice was patent. A previously placed plastic stent was seen emerging from the major papilla. The minor papilla could not be located. The ampulla was identified and found to be normal. Bile duct cannulation was attempted using a sphincterotome preloaded with a guidewire (0.035-inch guide wire) and was successful. Biliary cannulation was achieved without pancreatic duct entry. Contrast was injected under fluoroscopic guidance and a cholangiogram was performed. Intrahepatic ducts were normal in caliber, and contrast drained freely into the duodenum. A mild, short, hilar stricture measuring approximately 5 mm, extending from the hilum was noted. A single plastic stent was visualized at the major papilla and successfully removed. Pancreatogram was not performed. Sphincterotomy was performed. A 10 French by 15 cm plastic stent was placed. The scope was then completely withdrawn from the patient and the procedure completed. Estimated blood loss: None. Specimens removed: None. Complications: There were no immediate complications.

final_note: The rendered sections have been updated for consistency and readability based on the transcript. The chief complaints and past medical history have been corrected to reflect 'chronic calcific pancreatitis' instead of 'chronic thalassification pancreatitis'. The stricture description and plastic stent details have been clarified. The impressions have been formatted as a list for clarity.
